Subject: Activation functions and data types
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=noLTMWNYLaLGwOlX5WR6o6MJu3_6bxs_xxVTHt1IHdX0MDXLjaxJ
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

Q: What network activation functions are currently popular and what data types?

I understand very basic functions such as y = min(0, x) are in use, on
the basis that they posses the necessary non-linearity and are fast to
compute, as opposed to a classic sigmoid such as 1 / (1+e^-x) (with an
easy to compute derivative).

This question comes about because I was looking at optimising some
code that currently uses single precision floats (4 byte floats) to
use SIMD instructions (CPU instructions that operate on 4 *
single/floats), but then got thinking that if the activation functions
have been simplified then maybe everyone's using integers in their
code now? And if so what size integer?

And regardless of what is being used, what do you think should be
used? e.g. maybe bytes would be fine from a theoretical point of view
but aren't used due to GPUs being focused on single/float?

Colin
